text:
ADAPTATION

Adaptation, in biology, the process by which a species becomes fitted to its environment; it is the result of natural selection’s acting upon heritable variation over several generations. Organisms are adapted to their environments in a great variety of ways: in their structure, physiology, and genetics, in their locomotion or dispersal, in their means of defense and attack, in their reproduction and development, and in other respects.

A halophyte is a salt-tolerant plant that grows in soil or waters of high salinity, coming into contact with saline water through its roots or by salt spray, such as in saline semi-deserts, mangrove swamps, marshes and sloughs and seashores.

Hydrophytes are group of plants that have adapted to life in wet places or aquatic habitat. They have little to no root system because it is easier for them to obtain nutrients from water surfaces.

Bryophytes are a group of plant species that reproduce via spores rather than flowers or seeds.

Ferns reproduces through spores, not seeds, which are dispersed by a variety of methods, including water, gravity and animals, but the most common method of fern spore dispersal is wind.

Bryophytes grow in great masses and are very important in initiating soil formation on barren terrain, in maintaining soil moisture, and in recycling nutrients in forest vegetation. 

Humans and Monkeys can move their thumb farther across their hand than any other primate. Having opposable thumbs helps in grasping things more easily, picking up small objects, and eating with one hand. An opposable thumb is a physical adaptation.

Air Spaces in bird’s bones contained in the air sacs is an adaptation for flight, also only the vertebrae it the neck are flexible.

Amniotic egg is the type of egg produced by reptiles. Birds, and Protherian (egg laying mammals). It serves to provide nourishment throughout development. The embryo develops inside an amnion. The shell of the egg is either calcium based or leathery.

Clitellum is a thickened glandular and non-segmented section of the body wall near the head in earthworms and leaches, that secretes a viscid sac (cocoon) in which the eggs are deposited. The main function is therefore the protection of the eggs. It is located near the anterior end of the body. 

Dispersal of seeds and fruits is the scattering of seeds and fruits away, from the parent plant to avoid overcrowding, thereby reducing competition for food (nutrients), space, water, and air. Agents of dispersal are wind, water, animals and explosive.

Both mimicry and camouflage are forms of defense for a species. Camouflage is when a species can change their colors or patterns to match its environment to blend in, like a chameleon! And mimicry is when a harmless creature makes itself look dangerous, e.g. is moth having eye patterns on the wing.

A caryopsis (plural caryopses) is a type of simple dry fruit that is monocarpellate (formed from a single carpel) and indehiscent (not opening at maturity) and resembles an achene, except that in a caryopsis the pericarp is fused with the thin seed coat. Examples are wheat, oats, barley, rice, and corn

Cypsela is a dry single-seeded fruit that does not split open during seed dispersal and is formed from a double ovary in which only one ovule develops into a seed. It is similar to achene, and characteristic of members of the family Composite (Asteraceae), such as the dandelion and gray husks of a sunflower "seed".

Achenes are monocarpellate and indehiscent. Achenes contain a single seed that nearly fills the pericarp, but does not adhere to it. Examples of achenes include buckwheat.

The difference between a cypsela and an achene is the fruit's origin. A cypsela is formed from an inferior ovary and may have a pappus, the modified calyx composed of awns, scales, bristles, or feather-like hairs, attached to one end. An achene is formed from a superior ovary and does not have a pappus attached.

A capsule is not a nut because it releases its seeds and it splits apart. Nuts, on the other hand, do not release seeds as they are a compound ovary containing both a single seed and the fruit.

Mutualism is a symbiotic relationship in which both species benefit. An example of mutualism involves goby fish and shrimp

Commensalism: here relationship between two organisms in which one of the organisms is benefited while the other is neither benefited nor harmed. 

Parasitism is a symbiotic relationship in which one species (the parasite) benefits while the other species (the host) is harmed.

The lichen is a symbiotic association composed of both fungal hyphae (which is a thread-like fungal cells) providing protection and structure and algal cells (photosynthetic). The fungal partner is usually an ascomycete and is dominant to the alga which is a green or blue-green alga.

Symbiotic bacteria called rhizobia within the nodules, producing nitrogen compounds that help the plant to grow and compete with other plants. When the plant dies, the fixed nitrogen is released, making it available to other plants and this helps to fertilize the soil.

Mycorrhiza is a symbiotic association between a fungus and the roots of a vascular host plant. Mycorrhiza form a network of filaments that associate with plant roots and draw nutrients from the soil that the root system would not be able to access otherwise. Root development is accelerated by the fungus enhancing root absorption of nutrient. 

Rhizomes are found in some plants, and they are similar to stolons but grow horizontally at or below the soil surface and can be fleshy and thicker than stolons.

A bulb is modified plant organ that consists of a relatively large, usually globe shaped, underground bud with membranous or fleshy overlapping leaves arising from a short stem. A bulb’s fleshy leaves -which in some species are expanded leaf bases function as food reserves that enable a plant to lie dormant when water is unavailable (during winter or drought) and resume its active growth when favorable conditions again prevail. An onion is a commonly known bulb.

Parthenocarpy is the natural or artificially induced production of fruit without fertilization of ovules, which makes the fruit seedless. Stenospermocarpy may also produce apparently seedless fruit, but the seeds are aborted while they are still small. Stenospermocarpy can occur in mango as a result of cold temperature.

Parthenogenesis (parthenos = virgin, genes = born) The development of an organism from an unfertilized egg.

Pitcher plants are several different carnivorous plants which have modified leaves known as pitfall traps—a prey-trapping mechanism featuring a deep cavity filled with digestive liquid. The traps of what are considered to be "true" pitcher plants are formed by specialized leaves. The plants attract and drown their prey with nectar. Examples are Drosera, Dionaea muscipula, Nepenthes, Utricularia and sarracenia.

Cold-blooded animals are the animals which cannot regulate their internal body temperature according to the required level and they keep on changing their temperature according to the changes in external environment temperature. Although Warm-blooded animals attempt to keep their internal body temperature maintained and does not change the same along with changes in external environment.

Cold-blooded animals can be either terrestrial or aquatic. All reptiles, including snakes, lizards, turtles, tortoises, alligators, and crocodiles, some insects such as the busy dragonflies and bees, amphibians such as frogs, toads, and salamanders, as well as fish, including sharks, are all cold-blooded animals.

With a few exceptions, all mammals and birds are warm-blooded, and all reptiles, insects, arachnids, amphibians and fish are cold-blooded.

Moulting (or molting) is the way an animal routinely casts off part of its body (usually the outer layer or covering) at a particular time of the year, or at specific points in its life cycle. Moulting can involve the epidermis (skin), and hair, fur, wool, or other external layer.

 

UNN PUTME Example

1. The ability of an organism to survive in air environment successfully known as

A. residence B. adaptation, C. secession D. competition

(B. Adaptation, in biology, the process by which a species becomes fitted to its environment; it is the result of natural selection’s acting upon heritable variation over several generations, 2009/2010, no 14)

 

2. Bones of birds are modified for flight by

A. being long B. being cartilaginous C. containing air spaces D. being filled with Marrow

(C. Air Spaces in bird’s bones contained in the air sacs is an adaptation for flight, also only the vertebrae it the neck are flexible, 2005/2006, no 6)

 

3. One of the adaptations to life, on a tree by a monkey is its possession of digits which are

A. long B. opposable C. extensible D. big

(B. Humans and Monkeys can move their thumb farther across their hand than any other primate. Having opposable thumbs helps in grasping things more easily, picking up small objects, and eating with one hand. An opposable thumb is a physical adaptation, 2009/2010, no 15)

 

4. An animal shows resemblance with its surroundings. This phenomenon is called _____.

A. Mimicry B. Camouflage C. Ammensalism D. Photo-cooperation

(B. Both mimicry and camouflage are forms of defense for a species. Camouflage is when a species can change their colors or patterns to match its environment to blend in, like a chameleon! And mimicry is when a harmless creature makes itself look dangerous, 2011/2012, no 11)

 

5. Horizontal stems that grow below the ground often near the surface of the soil are

A. Rhizomes B. Bulbs C. Tubers D. Corms

(A. Rhizomes are similar to stolons but grow horizontally at or below the soil surface and can be fleshy and thicker than stolons)

 

6. When a plant bearing ripe fruits is swayed by the wind and in the process the seeds are scattered the phenomenon is called

A. wind dispersal B. censer mechanism C. winged fruits D. explosive mechanism

(Wind dispersal. Wind dispersed seeds are light and feathery they may have hairs, plumes etc and achieve dispersal using Censer Mechanism, 20115/2006, no 14)

 

7. Plants adapted to life in salty marsh are known as

A. hydrophytes B. xerophytes C. halophytes D. epiphytes

(C. A halophyte is a salt-tolerant plant that grows in soil or waters of high salinity, coming into contact with saline water through its roots or by salt spray, such as in saline semi-deserts, mangrove swamps, marshes and sloughs and seashores, 2007/2008, no 8)

 

8. The spores of ferns are dispersed by____

A. wind B water C. insect D. explosive mechanism

(A. Ferns reproduces through spores, not seeds, which are dispersed by a variety of methods, including water, gravity and animals, but the most common method of fern spore dispersal is wind, 2015/2016 II, no 1)

 

9. A dried fruit formed from two or more carpels containing several seed is_____

A. follicle B. legume C. capsule D. schizocarp

(C. A capsule is not a nut because it releases its seeds and it splits apart. Nuts, on the other hand, do not release seeds as they are a compound ovary containing both a single seed and the fruit, 2015/2016 II, no 3)

 

10. An onion is a bulb because it_____

A. has a tuberous stem B. has a reduced stem and thick fleshy leaves C. has adventitious roots D. bears many buds at the nodes

(B. has a reduced stem and thick fleshy leaves, 2015/2016 II, no 11)

 

11. The brightly coloured eye spots on the hind wings of a moth are an example of 

A. crypsis B. mimicry C. warning coloration D. disruptive coloration 

(B. mimicry is when a harmless creature makes itself look dangerous, 2018/2019, no 6)

 

 

12. In which of the following groups of plant fruits is the pericarp inseparable from the seed coat?

A. caryopsis B. nut C. follicle D. cypsela

(A. A caryopsis (plural caryopses) is a type of simple dry fruit—one that is monocarpellate (formed from a single carpel) and indehiscent (not opening at maturity) and resembles an achene, except that in a caryopsis the pericarp is fused with the thin seed coat. Examples are wheat, oats, barley, rice, and corn, 2009/2010, no 12)

 

JAMB Examples

1. Rodents gnaw on food with their 

A. molar teeth B. Strong jaws C. Flat- ridged teeth D. Chisel-like front teeth

(D. Chisel-like front teeth, 2018/2019, no 13)

 

2. Which of the following organisms is both parasitic and autotrophic?

A. Sundew B. Loran thus C. Rhizopus D. Tapeworm

(A. Sundew)

 

3. The bright coloured eye spots on the wings of moth are an example of

A. warning colouration B. disruptive colouration C. crypsis D. mimicry

(D. mimicry)

 

4. The special pigment for colour change in chameleon is

A. melanin B. carotenoid C. chromatin D. chromatophore

(A. melanin)

 

5. One of adaptation of Cactus opuntia to conserve water is the reduction of

A. internodes B. stem to leaves C. leaves to spine D. flower size

(C. leaves to spine)

 

6. Which of the following structures is a protective adaptive feature of the Agama Lizard to the environment? 

A. Nuchal crest B. Claws C. Scaly skin D. Gular fold.

(A. Nuchal crest)

 

7. The insect-trapping by the leaves of Venus flytrap is an example of a

A. adaptive coloration B. structural adaptation C. environmental adaptation D. behaviour adaptation

(B. structural adaptation)
